messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:50): wonders how donations to small software development efforts works
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:50): Like how does the money affect the development
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:51): I can understand "here is $x to do y"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:52): But "Here is $x to make it better" doesn't have any obvious impact unless sum($x_i) is enough for the developers to give up (part of) their outside job
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:53): Is anyone here working on the HTMLMediaElement spec?
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:53): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, I'd imagine part of the money is used for buying the hardware
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:54): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, but I trust them to do the right thing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:54): Oh I guess for a hardware driver project that does make sense
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:54): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0, as in editing it? I guess 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:55): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: i'm editing that part of html5 right now

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:55): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: I'm not suggesting you did anything silly. I'm just curious what the dynamics are when one donates to a (pure software) project
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Cool. I'm having some trouble with media events when the scrubber is clicked and dragged.
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:56): Some browsers fire a 'pause' when you click and hold the scrubber and others do not.
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:56): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, I hope it actually works; I've had issues using my MasterCard online
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:56): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Is one implementation correct, or is that not covered by the spec?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: that's basically a user interface issue, so it depends on whether the browser implementor wants the video to continue playing when you let go of the scrubber or not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: or whether they want it to play as you're dragging

467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (21:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, so the way this "Geopriv" works is that the user sets a bunch of variables and the author then either honors them or does his own thing?

a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:59): ok. The extra events are causing a problem for me in Firefox in particular. Perhaps I should bug them to fire extra events when the interface is interacted with.
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (21:59): afaik, both Firefox and Safari's interface is the same, but the events fired are different.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: as far as i can tell, except that the settings get set in the browser's ui instead of the page's ui, so the user thinks it's the browser who's going to control it (and who is to blame, of course, when it inevitably gets ignored)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:00): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: which events?
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:00): sends email
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Firefox fires play/pause when you drag the scrubber. Safari does not.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:01): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: note that the proposal isn't really geopriv, it's something else. Geopriv itself is an XML format for transmitting geo data with privacy controls, which i think makes a lot of sense (and has nothing to do with UI)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:01): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: does safari keep playing the video if you just hold the scrubber without moving it?
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: checking now
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, mkay, somewhat confusing title then
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Safari does pause playback when you drag teh scrubber.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:04): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: then that's a safari bug, it should be pausing the video in the api too

a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:06): ok. It would be nice from a JavaScript developer's perspective if there was a way to know whether the video was paused through clicking the pause button or paused through dragging the scrubber.
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:07): The way it's implemented in Mozilla at least, the two are impossible to distinguish.
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (22:11): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: If I'm filing a bug with Webkit, is that behaviour specified in section 4.8.10.11?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:14): a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0: yeah "Where possible (specifically, for starting, stopping, pausing, and unpausing playback, for muting or changing the volume of the audio, and for seeking), user interface features exposed by the user agent must be implemented in terms of the DOM API described above, so that, e.g., all the same events fire."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:22): got "here is $x to do y" for his font subsetting tool, which was nice and unexpected
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:23): hsivonen / 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: Re URLs: Oh, good point(s)
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:27): URLs? My memory is failing me... :/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:28): 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090612#l-305
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:43): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, the second of "similar note in audio codecs section" should have s/audio/video
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:48): d'oh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:49): btw
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:49): i hate software patents
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:49): 16bit wave? really? that's the best we can do?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:49): and nothing at all for video?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:49): what bs
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:51): is surprised that microsoft doesn't have patents on wave
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:51): apple won't implement codecs that have a submarine patent risk that they haven't already taken on
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:52): *everything* has submarine patent risk
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:52): lots of big companies have taken the risk with vorbis, including Microsoft IIRC
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:52): mozilla won't implement codecs that require patent licenses unless they can cover their redistributors, which they can't
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:52): opera won't implement codecs that require paying money
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:52): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: "that they haven't already taken on" is a key part of that sentence
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:53): and i'm not arguing about who's right or wrong
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:53): because frankly it doesn't matter
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, no, i mean implementing cross-site XHR has submarine patent risk
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:53): they could not want to implement codecs that didn't start with an "A" and we'd still be in the same boat
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, implementing @font-face has submarine patent risk
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:53): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: argue with them, not me
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, implementing anything new has submarine patent risk
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:54): you'll note my employer is implementing everything :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:54): ogg theora, vorbis, 264, you name it
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:54): well, I can't say that I'm happy your employer is implementing things with known patents
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:54): but that's a separate conversaion
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:54): well, actually it's related
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:55): yeah, well
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:55): if the unpatented formats didn't suck...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:55): but anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:55): i don't want to argue about it
058f354e300cae2f9755165ed8d5131c (22:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i really think that's no big deal for the spec, we'll see something similar to what happened with jpg, png and gif
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:55): i just want to whine that this makes my life hard from the html5 perspective

c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:56): the thing is, the "we won't implement anything with submarine patent risk" argument is BS. What it really is is "the risk/reward ratio isn't good enough right now"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:56): 058f354e300cae2f9755165ed8d5131c: maybe, though the codec space is _much_, _much_ more patent-encumbered.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:56): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: yeah i was simplifying their position for effect, you're right that it's really about risk/reward.
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:56): we can't do anything to lower the risk part, so we'll have to up the reward part
058f354e300cae2f9755165ed8d5131c (22:56): gif was patent-encumbered and yet everybody used it
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:56): which means that we have to get people to use ogg, and only ogg
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:56): the GIF patent only covered encoding
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (22:56): not decoding

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): 058f354e300cae2f9755165ed8d5131c: (a) it wasn't thought to be originally, (b) it was only encoding that was covered, so browsers were safe, and (c) yeah, that's why people are paranoid now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): i should go get lunch
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): bbl
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:58): 058f354e300cae2f9755165ed8d5131c, what hixie said. GIF isn't a proof doing patented stuff is fine. It's a lesson costly learned
a15c837b0887e540c7b430af1fc3c4f0 (23:03): Mozilla's doing some good work to make theora suck less.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:11): c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059: the key part is "not arguing about right and wrong"
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:13): oh wouldn't it be nice to take an amoral stance regarding <video>
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:14): Mozilla could drop Windows Media in there
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:14): and we'd have a lot of the Web taken care of
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (23:17): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4, isn't that sort of what enabling GStreamer does?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:18): yes, but if we did (have? not sure if we went for it) I would and do openly disagree that it is the right thing
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:19): I wouldn't make up some absurd rationalization
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (23:20): not yet apparently
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:20): yeah, I don't like it, but I also haven't spent much time working on the mobile product or the video element
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (23:21): (I actually thought it was in, but https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=422540 suggests it isn't)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:21): mozilla also doesn't publish mass quantities of h264 video
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:21): so there is that
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:22): anyway, the whole "some people have paid MPEG-LA, some people haven't, so it's a tossup" argument is just such bullshit
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (23:23): try applying that logic to any number of historical dilemmas
